sentence: The Home Depot Inc. ( HD ), the world's largest home specialty retailer, is scheduled to report its first-quarter 2012 financial results before the opening bell on Tuesday, May 15.
The current Zacks Consensus Estimate for earnings for the first quarter is 66 cents a share, which is better than 50 cents delivered in the prior-year quarter.
Revenue is expected at $17,940.0 million, according to the Zacks Consensus Estimate.
With respect to earnings surprises, Home Depot has topped the Zacks Consensus Estimate over the trailing four quarters of 2011, with an average surprise in the range of 1.7% to 19.1%.
This suggests that Home Depot has beaten the Zacks Consensus Estimate by an average of 6.9% in the past four quarters.
On February 21, 2012, Home Depot posted its fourth-quarter 2011 adjusted earnings of 50 cents a share.
The adjusted earnings not only surpassed the prior-year quarter's earnings of 36 cents (an increment of approximately 39%), but also outpaced the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 42 cents.
Moreover, the quarterly results were amplified by the increased number of centralized distribution centers and better merchandising tools.
Further, a mild winter season forced the spring demand to pick up, benefiting the quarter's performance.
Net sales moved up 5.9% to $16,014 million from $15,126 million in the prior-year quarter, beating the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $15,505 million.
The increase in net sales resulted from growth of 5.7% in overall comparable store sales.
In the U.S., comparable store sales rose 6.1%.
Following the better-than-expected fourth-quarter results, management anticipates 2012 diluted earnings per share to increase 13% year on year to $2.79 (after share repurchases).
Moreover, management is expecting growth of 4% in total sales on the back of low single-digit comparable store sales growth.
Gross margin is expected to expand moderately, while operating margin may see an expansion of 50 basis points.
The company is planning for a capital expenditure of approximately $1,325 million and anticipates generating free cash flow of $6,600 million.
Further, the company also plans to open 11 new stores and repurchase nearly $3,500 million of its common stock.
Estimates have moved up for the upcoming quarter and the full year, reflecting the positive bias of analysts due to the encouraging forward sales and earnings guidance.
For the first quarter of fiscal 2012, 15 out of 20 analysts revised their estimates in the upward direction with no downward revision in the last 30 days.
For full fiscal 2012, 15 out of 24 analysts revised their estimates in the positive direction, while none moved in the opposite direction, in the last 30 days.
In the last 7 days, 7 analysts moved their estimates up for the first quarter as well as for full year.
None of the analysts moved any estimate down for both the periods.
The Zacks Consensus Estimate for the first quarter spiked by 3 cents per share in the last 30 days and reflected an upside of 1 cent per share in the last 7 days.
Similarly, full year 2012 estimates witnessed an upside of 4 cents in the last 30 days and 2 cents in the last 7 days.
Home Depot is the leading player in the highly fragmented home improvement industry.
The company has reinvigorated itself with a shift in focus from new square footage growth to maximization of productivity through its existing store base.
In addition, the company has implemented significant changes to its store operations to make them simpler and more customer friendly, thereby inducing more customer traffic.
We believe these initiatives will attract more customer traffic to its stores and in turn boost its top line.
Moreover, with the introduction of a new warehousing and transportation system, the company has been able to improve its supply chain while minimizing cost.
This has also helped Home Depot to improve its Central Automated Replenishment System to facilitate immediate refilling of stock while reducing the investment in inventory.
Moreover, Home Depot will remain focused on optimum capital allocation, which will further increase shareholders' wealth.
However, given the current economic environment, we believe that spending on big remodeling projects will likely remain under pressure in the near term.
This leads us to keep our long-term recommendation on the stock at 'Neutral'.
Home Depot, which competes with Lowe's Companies Inc. ( LOW ) currently maintains a Zacks #2 Rank, which translates into a short-term 'Buy' rating.
